commentary.line: That brings an end to our coverage of this game. Hope you enjoyed it as much as we did while covering it. The extravaganza continues. Tomorrow it is Sri Lanka taking on Scotland. Though the Asian team has qualified, it will be an opportunity for Scotland to leave a mark. Join us for that game. Till then, goodbye and take care.
Check out some of the interesting stats from this game:
India have never lost an ODI when Shikhar Dhawan has scored a hundred. Today, he hit his 8th ODI ton.
Shikhar Dhawan joins Sachin Tendulkar to score two 100s as opener for India in a single World Cup. Tendulkar did it twice.
174-run opening stand between Rohit Sharma & Shikhar Dhawan is the best opening stand for India in World Cups.
This is the first time that India have bowled out their opponents in 5 consecutive ODIs.
Let's take a look at some of the interesting tweets pertaining to this game:
@OptaJim: 178 - Only Trent Boult (186) has bowled more dot balls at #CWC15 than @ashwinravi99 (178). Restricted.
@G_Rajaraman: India's unexpected story in #CWC15 so far: Bowling unit shifts operations from 'Hopeless Drive' to 'Revival Avenue'.
@cricketaakash: Two centuries in 5 games for Dhawan...spectacular return to form. Best part is that he's making it count.
@TomMoodyCricket: Another #WorldCup hundred to @SDhawan25, India a real force with their top order firing like this. #CWC15 #INDvIRE #Congrats
@narendramodi: Superb all-round performance. Congrats Team India! Keep up the momentum.
@mohanstatsman: India's 2nd biggest ODI win by balls (79) to spare while chasing a target of 250+ (but best in WC) #BingPredicts #DimagSay #INDvsIRE #CWC15
@dkmohanty: Most Wins by Indian Captains in World Cups, 12 MS Dhoni, 11 Kapil Dev, 10 M Azharuddin, 9 Ganguly, 1 S Venkatraghvan, 1 R Dravid #INDvsIRE #CWC15

"It feels good, definitely it means I have played with some really talented guys (talking about the winning streak). The last World Cup team was very good, playing in the sub-continental conditions, good mix of youngsters and at the same time good experienced players really helps. And without the five games in this tournament, it won't really have been possible. I think each and everyone really needs to enjoy it. It's not really about milestones, it is more about winning games for the country. So, I feel everyone is really happy about the fact that we have been able to win 9 consecutive games and we would like to take it forward as many games as possible because that's what the motive is. What's crucial is to see how the guys are batting. If you see Rohit (Sharma) and Shikhar (Dhawan) batting, they have been batting really well. Both of them have got runs and the icing on the cake could have been getting the runs together. This game was an ideal opportunity and I thought they made the most out of it. At times, when you are playing games like these, when you have qualified, it's difficult to put in the extra effort. But, I felt both the batsmen batted really well. They treated the delivery on the basis of how it was coming to them and initially I thought it could be a difficult wicket because it was stopping, but it kept getting better and better. And I feel now with a bit of dew around, it made it slightly good for the batsmen, but still you need to go in and score those big runs. I felt it was a good start from both the openers and Shikhar really capitalised on that and got a hundred. At the end of the day, nobody really remembers when you scored a hundred, what they remember is Shikhar Dhawan got 800 World Cup runs, 400 or 500 whatever. It is something that every batsman needs to do once you are set, make the most out of it, get hundreds, that's what people will talk about."

"At times I try to just tell them what my gut feel as to what the batsman is looking to do with a bit of initial movement or whatever I can read from behind. And Hindi is an ideal language to say it because everyone understands, but the batsman doesn't. So, I don't really have to walk up to them, to tell them what the batsmen maybe looking to do, but it's not that I am always right, but I feel it's important that if I get some kind of a gut feeling, I transfer it onto the bowlers, it doesn't mean that they have to bowl a particular delivery, I just ask them to be aware of it. Knowing the conditions helps. Yeah, it's a true fact that we have been here for over 4 months, we had to sacrifice somewhere and it had to be the intensity part. So, to some extent that was missing in the ODI series because the guys had put in a lot of effort in the Test series and it is almost the same batting line-up and the bowlers. So, I was pretty understanding of the fact, but at the same time it was important to step up and with the World Cup coming in, it automatically, it's the kind of support that we have got that really pushes us. So, I feel it was the right time to explode, think about the process but at the same time to go to the next level and I think all the boys have done that. Even in this game it was big a challenge for them, a lot of them were having jet lag. Coming from Perth and we landed close to 12 AM, then had a two-hour bus journey. So, a lot of them are still sleep deprived. So, I feel that was one reason why today's game was important and I am glad all of us stepped up."

Dhoni: "Well, one of the coaches was telling me (when asked whether he was aware about India bowling out their opposition for the 5th time in a row). It's a good stat to have. It means the bowlers are really doing their job for us. That's a remarkable difference. They have really stepped up and whatever the conditions maybe, I think they are bowling really well. I am not only talking about the three fast bowlers, also the spinners are complementing them. Whenever we have to use the part-timers, they have done well. So, it looks like a happy unit. After the first 3-4 overs I already knew I can easily bring on the spinners right now, but at the same I said let the fast bowlers get a bit of hit because they need to plan their innings. It was a slightly different wicket, less pace compared to the last the four games we had played. It was stopping just enough for the batsmen to play their shots, but still it was coming on nicely. I still went ahead with them, tried all the three fast bowlers, gave them a bit of go in the first 10 overs. Then, I said let's make the most out of this game. Get the part-timer also in, Suresh (Raina) I felt, with a lot of their left-handers in the team, I think he bowled really well, bowled the right pace and he ended up bowling 10 overs. So, I didn't have to try too many other bowlers."

Porterfield: "I don't think it can (replying to whether today's loss has dented their confidence). I think there is a lot of good things to take, especially in that first innings, we were slightly disappointed to come off, not having capitalised on what could have been, I think we could have got an extra 50-60 at least there, looking 320 plus. But every time we just kept up and it looked like kicking on again, we managed to lose a wicket coming down the back end. That was slightly disappointing. But as I said you have to give a lot of credit to them, the way they kept fighting and came back. And the way they played with the bat as well made it look very easy. I think it was a very good pitch. I think there was not a lot of help for the seamers. So, we managed to capitalise on that, on what was quite a small ground as well. We just couldn't kick on like the way their opening pair did, so that was a bit of a difference there. He (Ashwin) bowled really well and mixed his pace quite well, there was a bit of grip there at times, so we just lost a couple of wickets in that period as well. So, that slowed us down a bit, but then the way Nobby (Niall O'Brien) kicked on as well and picked up the momentum was great to see. And everyone that came in seemed to have that impetus which was great and play with the freedom, we just managed to lose wickets at the crucial times and that just slowed us down. But, I think all in all we played really well. We will get over it again and have rest and refresh again, coming down to this stage of the tournament, we have put in a lot of yards in the last 6-8 weeks. So, it's all about being mentally prepared and mentally fresh going into that game. We still have time for a couple of days of training when we get down to Adelaide, but it is obviously winner-takes-all in terms of ourselves. We win that game, we are through to the quarter-finals, so we have got to mentally prepare ourselves for that and we will be ready. It's not emotionally draining at all, we are at a World Cup, it's fantastic. You are playing in front of a full crowd. If you can't get going for these game, then you won't get going for many others. So, I don't think it is mentally draining, it's exciting."

Dhawan: "I have spent lots of time here and sorted out my game. It's good that I am used to the bounce and the pace and I am really enjoying my game over here. And I knew that I sort of got a game where I can play really nice on bouncy tracks. Now I can see that I am enjoying it. Of course everyone has spent a lot of time over here and the communication of the team has gone really up and I would like to thank the support staff, those who have put so much effort on the boys and especially our skipper. With time boys have learned, boys have got experience when we were playing such a big Test series and then tri-series and all those experiences coming in hand, everyone is doing a great job. It's lovely when we are on the field seeing our bowlers bowling so quick and on the right areas so consistently. The captain's message was to keep doing the same thing, with the same intensity and do the work with the same process. So, that's what we did and hopefully, our captain is going to be happy. I always mark myself 10 out of 10 (when Wilkins asked him to rate this innings). I will rate this innings, I will say I played more creatively, so I enjoyed that creativity today, playing different shots and using bowler's mind, so I will say that."
Shikhar Dhawan is the Man of the Match for his knock of 100

For India, Ashwin was yet again in great form as he flummoxed the batsmen with flight and guile en route to taking two wickets. After suffering at the hands of Ireland's openers, Stirling and Porterfield, Mohammed Shami came back well to snare three wickets. With this victory, India have won all their five matches till now. Ireland, on the other hand, will meet Pakistan in a do-or-die game.

Once Rohit and Dhawan were dismissed, Virat Kohli and Ajinkya Rahane took India to a convincing win. Earlier, despite Niall O'Brien's sterling knock, Ireland lost wickets in clusters to get bowled out for 259. After Ireland lost the wickets of Stirling and Ed Joyce in quick succession, it was Niall O'Brien, who took on the gauntlet of facing up to India's spinners, Ravichandran Ashwin and Ravindra Jadeja, and cracked some wonderful shots. Porterfield too amassed a fifty, but once Niall O'Brien was out, Ireland lost their way.

At the other end of the spectrum, Rohit, with his glorious artwork of batsmanship, played a sumptuous on-drive off Alex Cusack and then lofted Mooney over mid-off for a six. He also reached his fifty in style by playing an inside-out stroke off Stirling for yet another six. Eventually, Thompson took the wickets of Rohit and Dhawan, but by then, the damage was done. In fact, the 174-run stand for the first wicket turned out to be India's highest partnership for the opening wicket in World Cups

Once Dhawan got used to the lack of pace from Ireland's slew of medium pacers, he took his game to an elevated plane. He took a heavy toll off Stuart Thompson's wayward bowling by clouting him for a four and a six. When George Dockrell came into the attack, he threaded through the gaps and thumped three more fours. Once Dhawan reached his fifty, he used his feet to loft Stirling for a six and then used the depth of the crease to play the slog sweep in the same over. He also showcased the West Indian flair by shuffling across to pull Kevin O'Brien for a six.

Shikhar Dhawan and Rohit Sharma played with flair and panache to compose brilliant knocks and take India to a thumping victory by eight wickets. India now have won nine consecutive games under MS Dhoni's leadership in World Cups. In terms of successive victories in World Cups, Dhoni is now joint second with Clive Lloyd. It was Dhawan and Rohit, who tore apart a modest Ireland attack and collected runs with utmost ease. Dhawan had his fair share of luck, but he made them pay by essaying a ton.

The players shake hands. Kohli and Rahane congratulate each other with a hug. MS Dhoni now has 9 consecutive World Cup wins, the most by an Indian captain. He went past Sourav Ganguly, who had 8 wins in the 2003 World Cup. Dhoni is second on the list of captains with the most wins in World Cups, he is equal with Clive Lloyd and behind Ricky Ponting.

36.5   K O'Brien to Kohli, FOUR, India have recorded their fifth consecutive win in this World Cup. Kohli dispatches this with utter disdain. Full and outside off, he walked down the crease and hammered it past the cover fielder, long-off had no chance of cutting that off
36.4   K O'Brien to Kohli, no run, again, full and outside off, Kohli jams it on the wicket, the ball bounces over the stumps, lucky that it didn't go back onto the stumps
36.3   K O'Brien to Kohli, no run, too full and outside off, Kohli takes a step out of the crease, reaches out and squeezes it to backward point
36.2   K O'Brien to Rahane, 1 run, full and outside off, Rahane leans into the drive and creams it to sweeper cover

36.1   K O'Brien to Kohli, 1 run, Kevin O'Brien has hurt his hand. Bowls a juicy half-volley, Kohli drills it to the left of the bowler, O'Brien sticks his hand and tries to deflect it onto the stumps as Rahane was backing up, the ball was well wide of the stumps and the batsmen scamper across for a run
Kevin O'Brien [6.0-0-36-0] is back into the attack
India are one hit away from sealing the game.
35.6   Cusack to Kohli, 1 run, keeps the strike with a steer to short third man

35.5   Cusack to Kohli, FOUR, cracking shot! Short and outside off, Kohli stands tall and cracks the cut to deep backward point, not a muscle moved in the field as the ball whistled across to the fence

35.4   Cusack to Rahane, 1 run, shortish and outside off, Rahane dabs it to backward point, Kohli once more calls for a quick single, he gets there even as the fielder fires a throw at his end, mid-wicket doesn't back up in time, but there was the fielder in the deep
35.3   Cusack to Rahane, no run, good length ball on off, Rahane gets behind the line and defends down the wicket

35.2   Cusack to Rahane, FOUR, lovely shot! Rahane allowed the ball to arrive, opened the face of the bat and used the pace of the bowler, third man was inside the circle and he had no chance of cutting that off
35.1   Cusack to Kohli, 1 run, short of length on off, Kohli shuffles across a touch and tucks it to deep square leg
35.1   Cusack to Kohli, wide, splays it well down leg, Kohli stays inside the line and lets it go, wide called

34.6   J Mooney to Rahane, FOUR, edged and four! The third man fielder was square and the ball went very fine. It was full and on the fourth stump line, Rahane was looking for the flick, closed the bat face early and the leading edge runs away fine
34.5   J Mooney to Rahane, no run, slower and close to off, Rahane gets forward and turns it gently to short mid-wicket
34.4   J Mooney to Kohli, 1 run, another good looking cover drive, comes well forward, presents the straight bat and drives it towards cover, the fielder dives to his right and parries it to long-off

34.3   J Mooney to Rahane, 1 run, on a length just outside off, Rahane looks to drive and gets an inside edge onto the pad, the ball rolls away in front of point, Rahane looks at Kohli, who responds and sprints through for a quick single

34.2   J Mooney to Rahane, no run, tails back in from a length, Rahane stays rooted to the crease and is rapped on the pads, he missed the nudge through the on-side. Luckily for him, the impact was around off and the ball struck him a bit high on the pad

Loud shout for LBW and Porterfield signals for the review. Dharmasena was not interested. No issues with the no-ball, Mooney is fine with the front foot. Is height a factor? There is no wood on that. It hit him above the knee roll. Hawk-Eye shows impact as umpires call and it is also just clipping the top of the stumps. The onfield decision remains.
34.1   J Mooney to Rahane, no run, good length ball, bit of shape away outside off, left alone
Wilson continues to stand up to the stumps for Mooney..
33.6   Cusack to Kohli, no run, tad short and outside off, Kohli mistimes the punch to cover, he is disappointed. The bottom hand coming into play there as went too hard at it
33.5   Cusack to Rahane, 1 run, pitched up on off, Rahane drives it straight down the ground, long-on runs to his left and keeps it to a single
Jadeja is padded up and not Raina. The way these two are going, doesn't look like he will get a hit.
33.4   Cusack to Kohli, 1 run, back of a length around off, Kohli punches it wide of cover, for a single

33.3   Cusack to Kohli, FOUR, bad delivery and Kohli says thank you very much. Short and well wide of off, Kohli had all the time to pick his spot, he cuts it between backward point and short third man
33.2   Cusack to Rahane, 1 run, full and slanting in, Rahane leans forward and wrists it to long-on
33.1   Cusack to Kohli, 1 run, short of length on off, Kohli eases it off the back foot to the right of the bowler, Cusack can't get there and the duo go through with the run
Alex Cusack [6.0-0-23-0] is back into the attack

Drinks are on the field now. India are cruising comfortably, they might as well take the batting powerplay and finish it off. Well, looks like they read my mind, the umpire signals for the powerplay..

One has to give it to Porterfield for still keeping a slip for the very expensive Thompson. What else can Porterfield do? The Indians are batting so well, that even 400 looks chasable on this wicket. Maybe he wants to show that he still trusts his young bowler against some of the best batsmen in the world. But Thompson hasn't helped his skipper by bowling too full and giving the batsmen the room to drive and loft.
32.6   J Mooney to Rahane, no run, punched off the back foot to cover

32.5   J Mooney to Rahane, FOUR, it keeps getting better and better and better. This one is on a bent knee, width offered by Mooney and Rahane got forward to cream the drive, cover dived in vain again and this time sweeper didn't even bother to chase it down
32.4   J Mooney to Rahane, no run, full and on the pads, flicked straight to the fielder at mid-wicket
32.3   J Mooney to Rahane, no run, length ball, turned towards square leg, Rahane says no to Kohli for the quick single

32.3   J Mooney to Rahane, wide, was that a ploy to get Rahane out stumped on the leg-side? But Rahane never moved, down leg, Rahane flicks and misses. Wilson whips the bails off, good glovework standing up

32.2   J Mooney to Rahane, FOUR, now Rahane gets into the act. He gets forward and slightly reaches out, but times the drive so well, that he beats cover to his left and the sweeper to his right. Came right off the middle of the bat. So easy on the eye too
32.1   J Mooney to Rahane, no run, pushed to cover off the front foot
32.1   J Mooney to Rahane, wide, shortish and well outside off, Rahane reaches out to cut and misses. Wide called
John Mooney [4.0-0-28-0] is back into the attack
31.6   S Thompson to Rahane, 1 run, pushes this to long-on, and retains the strike with that run

31.5   S Thompson to Rahane, FOUR, that is a fine, fine late cut by Rahane. Rahane opens the face of the bat and delays the cut, then plays it very late and sends it wide of third man, running and diving across to cut it off, it was all in vain eventually
31.4   S Thompson to Kohli, 1 run, back of a length and outside off, straightens too, Kohli pushes at it, gets it wide of the diving point
31.3   S Thompson to Kohli, no run, Kohli presses forward and defends the good length delivery to point
31.2   S Thompson to Rahane, 1 run, back of a length outside off, Rahane cuts and finds third man, more of a thick outside edge of sorts that one
31.1   S Thompson to Kohli, 1 run, Kohli shimmies outside off, walks forward too and then times the on-drive wide of long-on, wanted two, but they settle for the single
30.6   K O'Brien to Rahane, no run, length ball, nudged towards square leg, no chance of a quick single as the fielder gets in quickly

30.5   K O'Brien to Rahane, FOUR, when the Indians are playing so well, half-volleys are like a red rag to a bull, that's what O'Brien does and he is punished. Rahane just timed that past Kohli and mid-on had no chance
30.4   K O'Brien to Kohli, 1 run, pitched up outside off, driven off the front foot to sweeper cover

30.3   K O'Brien to Kohli, 2 runs, so nearly four to just an open-faced dab, Thompson at third man initially felt that it was an easy couple and then realised he had to sprint, which he did and then put in the full length dive, saved two runs. Good effort. But again pristine timing from Kohli
30.2   K O'Brien to Kohli, no run, Kohli gets forward and then has to defend the length ball back to the bowler, O'Brien flicks the ball back to the keeper
30.1   K O'Brien to Kohli, no run, shortish outside off, cut straight to the fielder at point. Hit hard, but not in the gap
29.6   S Thompson to Rahane, no run, pitched up outside off, Rahane drives, but well-stopped by cover moving to his right
29.5   S Thompson to Rahane, no run, against Thompson, the two batsmen are really creaming it off the middle of the bat, this time Rahane with a drive to mid-off
29.4   S Thompson to Rahane, no run, pitched up outside off, Rahane gets forward and drives, very well, but straight to the fielder at cover
29.3   S Thompson to Kohli, 1 run, now a picture perfect off-drive as he walks forward and meets the ball on the rise, down to long-off
29.2   S Thompson to Kohli, 2 runs, back of a length outside off, rising too, Kohli controls the cut and gets it to the left of the diving point fielder, they take two

29.1   S Thompson to Kohli, FOUR, arrogance. Sheer arrogance from Kohli. Another step forward out, then almost takes it on the half-volley, drilled to the right of Rahane and gave mid-on no chance. How well-timed was that? The bowler too is impressed by that, puffs his cheeks out and just walks back to his mark
28.6   K O'Brien to Kohli, 1 run, on a good length and Kohli gets forward to play a sweet off-drive, to long-off
28.5   K O'Brien to Rahane, 1 run, back of a length outside off, Rahane punches it to sweeper cover
28.4   K O'Brien to Kohli, 1 run, pushed to the right of point, Rahane makes it home with a full length dive, the throw missed anyway and even if it had hit, Rahane was home
28.3   K O'Brien to Kohli, no run, length ball on off, Kohli closes the face of the bat too early, a leading edge is found, but rolls along the ground and to the left of O'Brien
28.2   K O'Brien to Rahane, 1 run, full and on middle, wristed wide of mid-on
28.1   K O'Brien to Kohli, 1 run, back of a length outside off, Kohli pushes away from the body and gets a sort of an outside edge, but safely to third man
27.6   S Thompson to Rahane, no run, on a good length and outside off, left alone
27.5   S Thompson to Kohli, 1 run, length outside off, punched off the front foot, beats the diving cover who parries it to long-off
Ajinkya Rahane, right handed bat, comes to the crease

27.4   S Thompson to Dhawan, out Caught by Porterfield!! Excellent catch and Kohli pats Dhawan on the head as he walks past him. Dhawan wanted to finish the game off as soon as possible, went for the leg-side hoick, was early into the shot, the leading edge seemed to be landing in no-man's land, but Porterfield ran back from cover and held on with both hands over his shoulder. Never an easy catch that, but Porterfield made it look easy. Tumbled down and then got up to be surrounded by his mates. Dhawan walks off to a standing ovation from the Seddon Park faithful - 11,000 odd and something. Dhawan c Porterfield b S Thompson 100(85) [4s-11 6s-5]
S Thompson to Dhawan, THATS OUT!! Caught!!
27.3   S Thompson to Kohli, 1 run, pitched up outside off, Kohli drives to sweeper cover, just a single

27.2   S Thompson to Kohli, SIX, Kohli has had enough of Thompson. A step or two out and then thunders the length ball over long-on. What power in that hit, only bottom-hand doing the trick, a flat hit as the spectators had to duck for cover. Kohli certainly made a statement there
27.1   S Thompson to Kohli, no run, Kohli gets forward and plays a strong bottom-handed cover drive, but straight to the fielder at cover
26.6   K O'Brien to Kohli, 1 run, worked to deep backward square leg, Kohli retains the strike with that run

Dhawan got there with a clip through square leg, shuffles across and takes it on the full, exposed his stumps but managed to put it away. Raises the bat and takes the helmet off. His trademark celebration with both arms stretched out wide. Brilliant innings once again from him

26.5   K O'Brien to Dhawan, 1 run, there it is! 100 for Dhawan. His second hundred in this World Cup and how his fortunes have turned! Eighth overall in ODIs. Was this the same Dhawan who struggled so miserably against Australia all summer? Back then, he couldn't buy a run. Was even dropped for the last Test at Sydney. People were behind his back, some even questioning his place in the World Cup 15. Some wanted Murali Vijay to take his place in the final 15. What a way to respond to your critics. There is something about ICC tournaments and Dhawan! It certainly spurs him on

26.4   K O'Brien to Dhawan, no run, Dhawan is looking a tad nervy, in the last 5-10 minutes. This one is on the stumps, Dhawan drops it near his feet and looks for the impossible run, no chance as Kohli rightly sends him back
26.3   K O'Brien to Dhawan, no run, slower delivery from O'Brien, Dhawan gets forward and wrists it, but short mid-wicket dives to his right and keeps Dhawan on 99
Now he is on 99. The crowd know that and they are making quite a noise as they egg Dhawan on
26.2   K O'Brien to Dhawan, 2 runs, cut from the stumps square of the wicket, placed in the gap and Dhawan comes back for the second
26.1   K O'Brien to Kohli, 1 run, Kohli gets forward and takes a step outside off, wristed in front of mid-on, easy single
25.6   S Thompson to Dhawan, no run, fuller length outside off, Dhawan tried to muscle that through cover, but that spoils the timing, finds the fielder for the third time in the over
25.5   S Thompson to Dhawan, no run, slower delivery outside off, Dhawan waits for it and punches it to cover
25.4   S Thompson to Kohli, 1 run, Kohli won't miss out that time, a step forward and to the pitch of the ball before unleashing a lovely cover drive to sweeper cover
25.3   S Thompson to Kohli, no run, a repeat of the previous ball, but this time the ball is inside the guideline, Kohli plays the cover drive and misses
25.3   S Thompson to Kohli, wide, Kohli charges Thompson, the bowler bowls it full and outside the guideline, wide called. The bowler doesn't like the call
25.2   S Thompson to Dhawan, leg byes, 1 run, short of length and angling in, Dhawan looks for the short-arm jab, but misses and the ball goes off the thigh pad to fine leg
25.1   S Thompson to Dhawan, no run, slower delivery outside off from round the wicket, eased to cover where the fielder dives to his right and saves a couple at least
24.6   K O'Brien to Kohli, no run, Kohli is content to get his eye in, comes on the front foot and defends a length ball outside off to point
24.5   K O'Brien to Kohli, no run, another solid front foot defence to point
24.4   K O'Brien to Kohli, no run, Kohli closes the face of the bat too early to a middle stump delivery, a soft leading edge is found on the flick, but it rolls to cover
24.3   K O'Brien to Kohli, no run, on a good length and outside off, Kohli defends to point
24.2   K O'Brien to Dhawan, 1 run, on the pads, flicked to deep mid-wicket, for a single

24.1   K O'Brien to Dhawan, no run, Dhawan defends and the ball is going away from the stumps, but Dhawan moves towards the ball and ensures it doesn't spin back in to hit the stumps. Wilson fields. Both the keeper and the batsman have a word and smile about it
23.6   S Thompson to Kohli, no run, pitched up outside off, Kohli leaves again
23.5   S Thompson to Kohli, no run, pitched up outside off, Kohli leans into a lovely cover drive, but can't beat cover-point
23.4   S Thompson to Kohli, no run, nice flick, but straight to the fielder at square leg
23.3   S Thompson to Kohli, no run, back of a length outside off, Kohli has a sighter, left alone
Virat Kohli, right handed bat, comes to the crease

23.2   S Thompson to Rohit, out Bowled!! End of Rohit and some joy for the beleaguered Irish. Hint of nip back in for Thompson, Rohit was trying to run it down to third man, played with an angled bat and the inside edge clattered into leg stump. Rohit has missed out on an easy World Cup 100 against a very average Irish attack, on a belter. Rohit b S Thompson 64(66) [4s-3 6s-3]

However, once he got set, Dhawan thumped Cusack for a couple of boundaries. It could be said that early on in the innings, Dhawan struggled for touch due to the lack of pace from Ireland's slew of medium pacers. Dhawan certainly thrives on pace on the ball. He also took a heavy toll of some ordinary bowling by Stuart Thompson to thump him for a four and a six. Thompson looked rusty as this is his first game in this World Cup. Dhawan then cracked a well-deserved fifty.

Here is Bharath Ramaraj's analysis of the first 17 overs: Rohit Sharma presented the full face of the bat to play some glorious drives. In particular, the on-drive he essayed off Alex Cusack's bowling was a sumptuous stroke. He also lofted John Mooney over mid-off for a six. On the other hand, Shikhar Dhawan had his fair share of luck. Mooney dropped a caught and bowled chance and William Porterfield dropped a tough chance too.

Drinks are on the field now. I'm more than happy that drinks came at the right moment. It was getting unbearable to listen to the commentary on air, with all the stuff about food, table cloth and blah blah being spoken ad nauseam

Jamie Alter brings this update from the ground. "Some grey clouds hanging over one end of the ground. Could be a factor later on, especially if Ireland's seamers get busy."

Ashwin: "I thought they batted pretty well when they started. We had to pull it back, but we were confident that if we get a couple of quick wickets, things would change and that's what happened. It's a very good pitch. We've restricted them to a score that we would like to chase. Knowing MS (Dhoni), I don't think so (asked if it was pre-planned by Dhoni to bowl a lot spinners). It's an instinctive decision from him. They were struggling to push the ball for singles and that's why he got in more spinners. It was more about varying the pace for me on this surface. It is a conscious effort from me to bowl a lot slower, I have decided to bowl that way. I knew the wickets will come because of the five fielders inside the ring as batsmen will look to go over the top. All these ICC tournaments are about momentum and hopefully we will bat well and chase this down easily."

For a brief period, Niall O'Brien and Andrew Balbirnie raised genuine hopes of taking Ireland to a sizeable total, but losing the wickets of Balbirnie, Kevin O'Brien and Niall O' Brien at a crucial juncture of the innings didn't help their cause. For India, Ashwin continued his rich vein of form by bowling with control and took two wickets. Raina too did a commendable job in the middle overs. The Indian unit would be confident of chasing down this target. On the other hand, Ireland have an uphill task on their hands.

Umesh Yadav and Shami erred by bowling short on a flat deck and the batsmen duly took advantage of it. Both Stirling and Porterfield used the pull shot to good effect. They also played some stirring back foot punches. However, once the spinners were introduced into the attack, Ireland lost their way. Stirling was out to a soft dismissal and their key batsman, Ed Joyce, played a poor shot to lose his wicket to Raina. Mohit Sharma then sent Porterfield back to the pavilion after he constructed a fine fifty.

However, the bowlers made a superb comeback in the end overs by picking up a slew of wickets. In particular, Mohammed Shami snaring the wicket of Kevin O'Brien gave India the upper hand. Earlier, Stirling and William Porterfield gave a glimpse of their ability to play cracking shots on the back foot to put the Indian seamers under pressure.

Despite Niall O'Brien's enterprising knock, the Indian bowlers took wickets at regular intervals to bowl out the opposition for a below par total. This is the first time, India have cleaned up the opposition for five successive times in ODIs. In fact, after Ravichandran Ashwin, with subtle variations of drift, did a tremendous job to keep the batsmen in check and snaffle the key wicket of Paul Stirling, Niall O'Brien, played with fearlessness to take on the spinners. When MS Dhoni introduced the part-timer, Rohit Sharma, Niall O'Brien decided to up the tempo and scored a couple of boundaries. He then used the paddle sweep to place the ball into gaps and collected boundaries off Suresh Raina. He also clouted Ashwin and Ravindra Jadeja for sixes.
Thanks to Sanjay Manjrekar for this stat. This is the first time that India have bowled out their opponents in 5 consecutive ODIs.

DHONI's GEM: Dhoni never stops short of mincing words to his fielders and bowlers, when they are not putting their 100 percent on the field. This is what he told Ambati Rayudu, the substitute fielder, who was fielding at cover when Suresh Raina was bowling to William Porterfield. He says in Hindi: 'Paer dekh zara, uska paer dekh kaise hil raha hain, uske hisaab se anticipate kar, volleyball ki tarah khada hua hain beach pe'

The English translation of the above lines is - Look at how he is moving his feet, you have to anticipate where the ball will go, you are just standing there like you are playing a volleyball game on the beach.
The batting powerplay yielded 41/2 for Ireland

In fact, for a brief period, it seemed like Joyce's wicket would be a blow to Ireland's chances of amassing a sizeable total on the board. He isn't just in fine form in this tournament, but ever since he was praised by Shane Warne for his ability to tackle his box of tricks on a rather difficult track and score 70 against Hampshire at the Rose Bowl in Southampton in May 2005, he has been known as one of the better players of spin in the Ireland set-up. But the credit has to go to Ireland, as they have recovered well.

Here is Bharath Ramaraj's analysis of the last 21.4 overs: The Indian spinners tightened the screws on the Irish batsmen and were able to keep the opposition in check. The track is offering a bit of grip and Ireland have been tentative against the spinners. Ravichandran Ashwin has been in superb form in this World Cup and he yet again flummoxed the batsmen with his flight and guile and bowled parsimoniously. Suresh Raina also made his presence felt by taking the key wicket of Ed Joyce. With the batsmen struggling against spin, MS Dhoni also introduced Rohit Sharma into the attack. It was Niall O'Brien, who decided to take on the part-timer, Rohit, and essayed a couple of boundaries. He also thwacked Ashwin for a six down the ground. However, Dhoni missed a stumping chance off Raina's bowling to give William Porterfield a reprieve. But he didn't survive for long as Porterfield was dismissed by Mohit Sharma. O'Brien though, has looked in very good touch.
Drinks are on the field now . Can we make this a 60-over contest? India have bowled 39 overs in just 2 hours and 20 minutes.

Porterfield's opening partner, Paul Stirling, is another batsman, who is good at playing the pull and the cut. Mohammed Shami tried a short ball and Stirling too used the pull to thump him for a six. He and Porterfield also essayed fine back foot punches. It was surprising to see the Indian pacers banging it short to batsmen, who are fine back foot players and on a deck that is flat. In short, after playing at the WACA, the Indian seamers struggled to make the adjustment with the new ball. MS Dhoni then introduced the spinners into the attack, and Ravichandran Ashwin was able to stem the run flow to some extent and was rewarded with the wicket of Stirling. Stirling won't be happy with that soft dismissal. Suresh Raina then cleaned up Ed Joyce by pushing it through and Joyce paid the price for looking to play the cut shot.

Here is Bharath Ramaraj's analysis of the first 17.2 overs: Ireland started their innings on a very good note. It was William Porterfield, who slashed at a short and wide delivery from Umesh Yadav to collect Ireland's first boundary. He then used the pull shot to clout Umesh for a six on the back foot. Porterfield, who plays for Warwickshire, is known for his ability to play well on the back foot in the County circuit.

Pitch Report: "The pitch looks very good. It looks flat. There is a hint of grass but because of the sun, I don't think it will be an issue. Maybe, when the sun goes down the fast bowlers might get a bit of assistance. It should be a very good battle. I think we are in for a very good game with lots of runs today," reckons Sunil Gavaskar.
Teams:
India (Playing XI): Shikhar Dhawan, Rohit Sharma, Virat Kohli, Ajinkya Rahane, Suresh Raina, MS Dhoni(w/c), Ravindra Jadeja, Ravichandran Ashwin, Mohammed Shami, Umesh Yadav, Mohit Sharma
Ireland (Playing XI): William Porterfield(c), Paul Stirling, Ed Joyce, Andrew Balbirnie, Niall O'Brien, Gary Wilson(w), Kevin O'Brien, John Mooney, George Dockrell, Alex Cusack, Stuart Thompson
Ireland have won the toss and have opted to bat

Dhoni: "The conditions are slightly different, the outfields are smaller over here (talking about the difference in conditions between New Zealand and Australia). But, from the last tour what we have learned is, the wickets are pretty good. It comes on nicely and it remains the same. There is not a lot of changes apart from the fact that you have to adjust to the outfield being slightly smaller when you compare it to Australian soil. We were looking to bowl first. In this tournament so far there have been fair instances where we have put runs on the board. The last game was the only one where we chased (Dhoni forgot about the game against UAE), so it gives us another opportunity to chase a score. I think this is to some extent is the slowest New Zealand wicket. It's one place where the spinners get a bit of assistance. It's not a lot of assistance, but still they love to bowl over here. Apart from that, it's a good atmosphere whenever we play in New Zealand, it's a lovely beautiful place. We are going in with the same squad. We just want to go ahead with the good work that we have been doing. Also at the same time, it gives the team that settled time. They need to do what they need to do, but at the same time it gives them good exposure."

Porterfield: "It's a great place to be, obviously three from four (wins). We are looking forward to today and we will be trying for two points. We are going to bat first. Looks a pretty good surface, so get out there and make first use of it with the bat. It's obviously another big game, two points up for grabs. We had a look at India. It's been a slightly shorter turnaround between games for ourselves, but that can be a good thing as well, the way we are going. We have to start well now and continue our good form. We have made one change, McBrine misses out and Thompson comes in."

Our man, Jamie Alter, is at the ground and he says it's sold out, "Warm afternoon here in Hamilton, the CWC theme song is playing on the PA, the Indian fans have been here for a while, decked up in all sorts of outfits, Sudhir Gautam has blown his conch shell, taken photos with fans, and there are a scattering of Ireland supporters too. A good afternoon for cricket."
William Porterfield - "Obviously, we've got to try to restrict them with the ball and take wickets." Porterfield's mantra to win against India
Quotes: Mohit Sharma - "If you are a fast bowler, you do tend to bowl bouncers." Talking about his repeated use of the short ball in this tournament
Weather update: Conditions for the game are expected to be fine. It may be a bit overcast, but there is no rain predicted on the day of the match.
Ireland: Andy McBrine may play as the second spinner considering the small dimensions of the ground at Seddon Park. So that means Ireland too may go in with an unchanged side for this game.

Pre-match team news, India: India are likely to go in unchanged from their previous game. Having already qualified for the quarter-finals, India could've tested their bench strength but Dhoni isn't too keen on doing that.

"It's a nice position to be in. It's one we want to be in. The quarter-finals is a goal we set ourselves before we came here, so we're in a nice position now, but it doesn't count for anything if we don't keep getting good performances," said Porterfield.

Some news from the Irish camp ahead of the game, with captain William Porterfield terming this match "like any other game." "We've gotten into each game with two points up for grabs, and tomorrow isn't any different," he told reporters on Monday. "We've approached each game with great clarity and great professionalism really from our point of view, and we've prepared very well. It's a quicker turn around now from this game than from what we've necessarily had before, but it's a good place as I said before, that we're in, and we've got to start fresh tomorrow and come start time. So like any other game we're going into it looking for a win, and we're looking to make it four out of five tomorrow."

One man who has quietly slipped into his role without any fuss is the vastly under-rated Indian seamer Mohit Sharma. He has six wickets in four games at a superb economy of 3.90 to support Mohammed Shami, Umesh Yadav and Bhuvneshwar Kumar. "My role is very simple. When Shami and Umesh create that pressure, I have to maintain that pressure. I have to maintain that pressure for Ashwin and Jadeja too," he said on Monday. "The way Shami and Umesh bhai are bowling has helped me a lot. They have been bowling really well and have been able to exert a lot of pressure up front. My job is to maintain that pressure, so that Ashwin and Jadeja are benefitted from it later. So it helps me a lot that the batsmen are under pressure and my job then will be to bowl to my strengths; that I have been doing for the last 10 years. I just have to maintain my line and length and bowl according to the wicket."

Dhoni wanted Jadeja to come to the party, saying "Jadeja will have to step up. I feel his slot is very important if he starts scoring runs consistently for us." He continued - "Even though Jadeja is not performing really well as a batsman, he still gives you that comfort at six or seven and it looks like a slightly better side. We also have to keep in mind the over rate because a lot of people dig into the stats. Someone told me whenever we have played with four fast bowlers, 90 percent of the time we lose and 100 percent of the time the captain gets banned. It becomes a difficult one, but at the same time as I said, hopefully the spinners, they would have learned from the last outing in New Zealand."

India were tested for the first time in the tournament after three convincing wins. It was a good workout for the Indian side ahead of the knockouts. Sourav Ganguly certainly feels the same way. He had this to say, writing in his column: "It was a very good win for India against West Indies yesterday and when I say it was a very good win, there are reasons for it. The wins against South Africa and Pakistan were brilliant, but it was a hard-fought win yesterday. When you go through such a long tournament, you need this type of win to actually get the train back on track or the team back on track. I think India were outstanding yesterday. They lost the toss for the first time against a big team and I thought it was a good test for India. This World Cup has been all about teams batting first, putting big scores on the board and putting the scoreboard pressure on the team batting second. So, from that point of view, it was a very good workout for India."

If the Indians thought they were in for an easier time, they had to think again. The West Indies, inspired by Curtly Ambrose's pep-talk at the start of India's innings, came out and bowled with fire and brimstone. They had India 6 down with still 49 needed. But MS Dhoni and Ravi Ashwin - with some help from Jason Holder, who inexplicably bowled Samuels and Dwayne Smith when, the situation was crying out for Jerome Taylor - steered India home to make it four out of four.

So had enough of Ireland? Let's move on. Let's focus on India for a bit. On the back of three consecutive wins which included two over Pakistan and South Africa, India came into their game against West Indies at Perth as firm favorites. West Indies were bundled out for 182 as none of their batsmen showed application on a pacy and bouncy pitch. Only Jason Holder showed grit and made his second consecutive fifty of the tournament.

Alex Cusack, though held his cool and took the last two wickets to make it three wins out of four for Ireland. They sit on 6 points and face India and Pakistan in their last two games respectively. A win in either of those two games will ensure qualification for the quarter-finals. But two tough games to come. But as William Porterfield said, their destiny is in their own hands.

What happened in Ireland's last game against Zimbabwe? Ed Joyce continued his superb form by scoring a hundred and was assisted by Andrew Balbirnie with 97. A huge score of 331 was posted by the Irish. Brendan Taylor and Sean Williams fought for Zimbabwe. Sean Williams' catch by John Mooney was the turning point of the game. That catch had controversy written all over it as replays showed that Mooney's foot was touching the ad-cushions when he completed the catch. But Sean Williams had left the field of play - as soon as he got out and didn't wait - and that was the end of the story. Mupariwa battling on gamely, gave Ireland some nervy moments with 16 runs off 4 balls in the 49th over. That left Zimbabwe needing 7 off 6 balls in the final over.

Now let's take a look at how Ireland have done in this tournament so far. Ireland once again showed why they are such a fine side, winning against West Indies after giving away 304. They comfortably chased that down, winning with 25 balls to spare. That set them up nicely for the remaining fixtures and sent a message that they were one of the serious contenders for a quarter-final spot.

March 2nd, 2011 was Ireland's greatest night on a cricket field. Can they go one better? Can they slay another giant? This time - it's India who are waiting as we welcome you all to our coverage of the game being played at Seddon Park, Hamilton. If Ireland win today, they are assured of a place in the knockouts. What better incentive than that, to go out and play the game of your lives. So let's get started and rolling then.

Have a read and understand this. During the 2011 World Cup, the ICC had decided to have only a 10-team World Cup for 2015. That meant no place for the Associates or any of the "minnows". Ireland's win over England played a significant part in ICC changing its decision. Eventually the 2015 World Cup was played by 14 nations, giving the likes of Ireland another chance to showcase their giant-killing skills.

"It's annoying in the extreme, but I'm not taking anything away from Kevin O'Brien and the performance of his life," Swann added. "It's the best knock I've seen in a long time. If a guy gets 100 off 60 balls [sic], a guy gets 100 off 60 balls. There's not a lot you can do, except say we should have bowled differently - and in the next game we will do. If we start panicking and thinking we're the disgrace that half the people on Twitter thought we were last night, there's no point in us playing."

It was a completely different reaction from the England camp and understandably so. One man who was left shell-shocked by the result was Graeme Swann. "If we are going to win this World Cup - which we truly believe we can - we've got to go out and prove it, and we do that first and foremost in the field," said Swann. "Four or five days ago, the whole world was saying 'Oh my God, England can win' this - because we didn't get destroyed by that invincible Indian team. We know the fickle nature of the world, and we're going to ignore that and just carry on and play the best cricket we can."

Ireland's winning captain, William Porterfield said the team was yet to understand the enormity of their achievement. "We got to let this sink in still," he said. "We've all grown up dreaming of moments like this in a World Cup, and we're going to enjoy this time with our family and friends and have a couple of drinks."

Kevin O'Brien's father, Brendan "Ginger" O'Brien, was a happy man and he told the Belfast Telegraph this: "It's a hugely proud moment for me and I'm delighted for him. He had a couple of ducks recently but it is a hard game and he has come back well. We knew the wicket was good, the outfield very quick. Alex and Kevin were fantastic."

The Irish Times's Emmet O'Riordan was all praise for Kevin O'Brien, introducing him like this - "Crash, bang, wallop. Hello world, I'm Kevin O'Brien and I can hit a cricket ball." Continuing on - "It was brutal in its nature, the pick of England's bowlers belted to all parts of the stadium to huge cheers from both the Irish contingent of about 200 fans and the locals, who enjoy both an underdog and a big-hitter. Kevin O'Brien jarred his knee and ankle fielding a drive from Strauss in the covers. Tough as old boots, O'Brien junior was up and running after a blast of the magic spray, although after what transpired later, police may be looking for a local witch doctor."

The Examiner - an Irish newspaper responded with this to the win - "Memories of 2007, and comparisons with the World Cup victory over Pakistan in Jamaica will inevitably be made. But this was even better. England have hit their four highest World Cup totals in the last four games, are champions in the Twenty20 format of cricket, and are highly fancied to win this tournament. They are far better and more disciplined than the Pakistan side of 2007. Ireland have improved immeasurably since that breakthrough victory in the Caribbean. Thirteen of the 15-man squad are now full-time cricketers, and they are part of a 32-county squad that represents the whole nation of Ireland and sings 'Ireland's Call' as their anthem. They come with a self-belief and mental strength that sees them view results like this as just rewards."

Ireland just managed to win only one game after their win against England. But they were more than happy to put one past their rivals. Rob Bagchi writing for the Guardian newspaper had this to begin his piece: 'Until Wednesday Johnston, Mooney and O'Brien was simply an Irish bakery firm, famed for its Toastie loaf and slogan "live life, love bread". For one day at least Trent Johnston, John Mooney and Kevin O'Brien have made the three names more synonymous with triumphant glow than dough.'

England made 327 and looked well on course for an easy win when they had Ireland 5/111. Enter Kevin O'Brien or KOB as he is fondly referred to. He smashed the English bowlers to all corners of the Chinnaswamy as he recorded a 50-ball hundred - the fastest ever World Cup hundred. England were left shell-shocked by the brutal assault. England had James Anderson, Stuart Broad and Tim Bresnan, with Swann being the lead spinner. No-one was spared by the man nicknamed "Ginger" as Ireland went ballistic after the winning runs were hit.

March 2nd, 2011 was an epochal night in the annals of Irish history. Playing against their arch-rivals and close neighbours, England, there was a lot of pride and history attached to the clash. Historically, relations between the two states have been influenced heavily by issues arising from their shared (and frequently troubled) history. So when the two met at the Chinnaswamy Stadium in Bangalore, there was a lot to play for.

The 1996 edition saw Kenya beating West Indies. That was a massive upset. Bangladesh did the same to Pakistan in 1999. In 2003, Kenya, against all odds performed impressively and reached the semi-finals - albeit helped by a walkover from New Zealand - with wins over Sri Lanka and Zimbabwe, far superior sides than the Kenyan outfit. In 2007 Bangladesh beat India in one of the biggest upsets in World Cup history. India were knocked out before the Super Eights and forced a legend like Sachin Tendulkar to have doubts about his cricketing future.

12:30 Local Time, 23:30 GMT, 05:00 IST: The World Cups are the stage for the biggest upsets in cricketing history. It all started in 1983 when India stunned West Indies at Old Trafford before going on to repeat the dose in the final - which sent shockwaves amongst the cricketing community. The Duncan Fletcher-led Zimbabwean side came into the spotlight in the same tournament when they stunned Australia at Trent Bridge, Nottingham. The Australia side had the likes of Dennis Lillee, Jeff Thomson, Rod Marsh, Rodney Hogg and was led by Kim Hughes. Australia were definitely the favorites going into the game, but Zimbabwe came out trumps.

Preview by Jamie Alter

India. Unbeaten. Top of the Pool B table. The first team to reach the quarter-finals from the group. Defending champions.

Ireland. Three wins from four, two by the skin of their teeth. Tied on points with South Africa, who thrashed them, and Pakistan, who they play their final league match against. Desperate to make the quarter-finals.

Match 34 of the 2015 ICC Cricket World Cup pits these two teams together at Seddon Park on Tuesday, with India seeing this fixture as an opportunity to fine-tune a couple of loose ends and Ireland entering it hoping to put up a challenge from which passage to the knock-outs becomes easier.

While for India this match follows four matches in Australia which they won, for Ireland this is a much bigger fixture. At fourth in Pool B with six points from four matches, Willam Porterfield's team are in a desperate battle with Pakistan and West Indies to secure one of the two remaining qualifying spots. After India, Pakistan remain. It is not, whichever way you look at it, an easy task for Ireland.

And yet Porterfield played down the opposition by choosing to focus on what Ireland have done until this point, terming this match "like any other game."

"We've gotten into each game with two points up for grabs, and tomorrow isn't any different," he told reporters on Monday. "We've approached each game with great clarity and great professionalism really from our point of view, and we've prepared very well. It's a quicker turn around now from this game than from what we've necessarily had before, but it's a good place as I said before, that we're in, and we've got to start fresh tomorrow and come start time. So like any other game we're going into it looking for a win, and we're looking to make it four out of five tomorrow.

"Obviously, we've got to try to restrict them with the ball and take wickets. It's just like any game of cricket and in this format the best way of restricting teams is taking those wickets. So we've got to go out there with that mentality throughout the 50 overs of taking wickets. Whatever we do of the first ten overs is going to be big, with the bat or with the ball, we have to start the game well and get into it."

Being one point away from the quarter-finals was exciting for Ireland, but their skipper was not getting carried away. "It's a nice position to be in. It's one we want to be in. The quarter-finals is a goal we set ourselves before we came here, so we're in a nice position now, but it doesn't count for anything if we don't keep getting good performances," said Porterfield.

After starting their campaign with a four-wicket chase of 305 against West Indies in Nelson, Ireland scraped past UAE by two wickets with four balls in hand, lost to South Africa by 210 runs and pipped Zimbabwe by five runs in a tense match in Hobart two days ago. They will know full well that India will not let them go. The loss to South Africa has dented Ireland's net run-rate (-0.820), and so getting big runs on board becomes imperative.

One letdown for Ireland has been Kevin O'Brien, arguably their most high-profile player because of his stunning century that helped beat England in the last World Cup. The big-hitting allrounder has conceded runs at 9.60 and over, and in the narrow loss to Zimbabwe he conceded 90 in ten overs, of which 18 came in the 49th over. The opener and offspinner Paul Stirling has also faded away after he was named Man of the Match in the win over West Indies; he has tallied 22 runs in three innings since that eye-catching 92 and taken just two wickets. Ireland's bowling is their weak link, and the margin of error will be small against India.

On a small ground, getting your lengths right will be massive. India's pace attack has performed very well in keeping teams to small totals - only once has an opposition scored more than 200 against them in the tournament - and against Ireland's batsmen, who are used to playing in seam-friendly conditions in the UK, they can be expected to use the same approach.

Mohit Sharma, the seamer playing his first World Cup, spoke of the short ball being a method of wickets for him. "If you are a fast bowler, you do tend to bowl bouncers," he told reporters a day ahead of the match. "Yes, there is pace and bounce in these wickets Nobody expects my bouncer to come so fast because it skids as well. That's a plus for me because my bouncer skids a lot which catches the batsmen off guard and as a result there will either a top edge or they will get beaten. I have been hit for fours and sixes also off my bouncers but that's how it goes."

India have most bases covered. They have bowled and fielded beyond expectation, Shikhar Dhawan rediscovered his touch, Virat Kohli marked his second World Cup with a fine century and MS Dhoni has led well. Mohammad Shami, Mohit Sharma, Umesh Yadav and R Aswhin have taken 30 of the 40 wickets, but the lower middle order is a bit undercooked.

Suresh Raina, after a bullish 74 against Pakistan, has scored 28 runs in two innings, both times dismissed mistiming short balls. MS Dhoni deflected the question of Raina's continued struggles against short-pitched deliveries after the last match by terming it a media blow-up, but Ireland's seam-up attack will test out Raina. Ravindra Jadeja was called out by Dhoni in Perth to step up as a batsman - he has made 18 runs in three innings - which could throw into the mix Stuart Binny should India opt to rest Jadeja, more so because of his seamers which, under grey skies and on a skinny surface, will be handy to have.

India and Ireland have met just twice in ODIs. In 2007, India beat them by nine wickets in Belfast and then during the 2011 World Cup in Bangalore, by five wickets. India's record at Seddon Park is two wins out of eight, dating back to 1981. Last year, they lost both matches here to New Zealand. Ireland have never played at the venue.

Probable XIs

India: 1 Shikhar Dhawan, 2 Rohit Sharma, 3 Virat Kohli, 4 Ajinkya Rahane, 5 Suresh Raina, 6 MS Dhoni (capt/wk), 7 Ravindra Jadeja/Axar Patel, 8 R Ashwin, 9 Mohit Sharma, 10 Mohammed Shami, 11 Umesh Yadav

Ireland: 1 William Porterfield (capt), 2 Paul Stirling, 3 Ed Joyce, 4 Andy Balbirnie, 5 Niall OBrien, 6 Kevin OBrien, 7 Gary Wilson (wk), 8 John Mooney, 9 George Dockrell, 10 Alex Cusack, 11 Andy McBrine
